summary:
The University of Glasgow and TU Wien both demonstrate strong research contributions, particularly in Information Retrieval (IR), but with different areas of emphasis. TU Wien's research in IR spans user intent classification [1], document retrieval [2], and evaluation of retrieval systems [3], including a focus on health retrieval [3]. They have also explored local self-attention mechanisms for efficient document retrieval [2]. The University of Glasgow, on the other hand, has a strong focus on dense retrieval models [4], including static pruning [5] and query embedding pruning [6]. Both institutions have contributed to efficient information retrieval, but the University of Glasgow's work is more concentrated on dense retrieval techniques, while TU Wien's work is more diverse, including user intent and health retrieval. The University of Glasgow has also made significant contributions to pseudo-relevance feedback methods, specifically ColBERT-PRF [7], an area not explicitly mentioned in the TU Wien summaries. Furthermore, the University of Glasgow has a notable focus on diversification of search results for fairness and educational search [8], which is not a prominent theme in the TU Wien summaries. Finally, the University of Glasgow has contributed to the development of tools like PyTerrier [9] and datasets like Istella22 [10], indicating a focus on resources for the IR community.

**References:**

[1] Alexander, D., Kusa, W., & de Vries, A. P. (2021). ORCAS-I. https://doi.org/10.1145/3477495.3531737

[2] Hofstätter, S., Zamani, H., Mitra, B., Craswell, N., & Hanbury, A. (2020). Local Self-Attention over Long Text for Efficient Document Retrieval. https://doi.org/10.1145/3397271.3401224

[3] Althammer, S., Hofstätter, S., Verberne, S., & Hanbury, A. (2022). TripJudge. https://doi.org/10.1145/3511808.3557714

[4] Macdonald, C., & Tonellotto, N. (2021). On Approximate Nearest Neighbour Selection for Multi-Stage Dense Retrieval. https://doi.org/10.1145/3404835.3463254

[5] Acquaviva, A., Macdonald, C., & Tonellotto, N. (2023). Static Pruning for Multi-Representation Dense Retrieval. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-28238-6_11

[6] Tonellotto, N., & Macdonald, C. (2021). Query Embedding Pruning for Dense Retrieval. https://doi.org/10.1145/3404835.3463254

[7] Wang, X., Macdonald, C., Tonellotto, N., & Ounis, I. (2023). ColBERT-PRF: Semantic Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Dense Passage and Document Retrieval. https://doi.org/10.1145/3539597.3570402

[8] Yigit‐Sert, S., Altıngövde, İ. S., Macdonald, C., Ounis, I., & Ulusoy, Ö. (2021). Explicit diversification of search results across multiple dimensions for educational search. https://doi.org/10.1002/asi.24403

[9] MacAvaney, S., & Macdonald, C. (2021). A Python Interface to PISA!. https://doi.org/10.1145/3477495.3531656

[10] Dato, D., MacAvaney, S., Nardini, F. M., Perego, R., & Tonellotto, N. (2021). The Istella22 Dataset. https://doi.org/10.1145/3477495.3531656

input.prompt: Compare the contributions of TU Wien in the field of efficient information retrieval to the University of Glasgow contributions, over the last 5 years
